choices.text: Posterior interosseous nerve

questions.text: Identify the nerve involved in this test: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median nerve

 

SPECIAL TESTS FOR MEDIAN NERVE INJURY

 

  • Pen Test:
    • Test: Patient keeps his/her hand flat on the table and at the same time, examiner brings a pen above the thumb.
    • Interpretation: Patient tries to touch the pen by abduction the thumb and examiner feels the tendon of abductor pollicis brevis (APB) at the wrist. Patient fails to touch in APB paralysis and examiner will not be able to palpate the tendon.
    • Note: Median nerve invariably and exclusively supply APB.

 

 

  • Pointing Index Sign / Ochsner’s Clasping / Benediction Test:
    • Test: Patient clasps his both hand together.
    • Interpretation: The index finger fails to flex in median nerve injury and it points outward as pointing index.
    • Note: It occur in high median nerve palsy where flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus gets involved.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve. Special tests for ulnar nerve injury are:

 

  • Froment’s sign:
    • Test: The patient is asked to make a strong pinch between the thumb and index finger and grip a flat object such as a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger. The examiner then attempts to pull the object out of the patient’s hands.
    • Interpretation: There is weakness of the adductor pollicis innervated by the ulnar nerve which would keep the IP joint relatively straight; instead, the FPL muscle, which is innervated by the median nerve is substituted for the AP and will cause the IP joint to go into a hyperflexed position.

 

 

  • Wartenberg’s sign:
    • Test: The patient’s places wrist in neutral and forearm in full pronation and is instructed to perform full extension of all the fingers. Once digits are extended, patient is asked to fully abduct and then adduct all fingers.
    • Interpretation: A positive sign is indicated with the observation of abduction of the 5th digit, with the inability to adduct the 5th finger when extended.

 

 

  • Egawa’s sign:
    • Test: The patient flexes the middle digit & then alternately deviates the finger radially & ulnarly.
    • Interpretation: If the patient is unable to do this Egawa’s sign, the interossei are affected.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. Depending on injury severity there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Check strength of Biceps Brachii, Corocobrachialis and Brachialis muscles. Check sensation on lateral forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The test image shown in the question is the Pen Test, which is done to diagnose median nerve injury.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

 

  • Diagnosis based on the given image: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (PES)
  • PES is an age-related degenerative disorder, commonly seen in women.
  • Characterized by deposition of an amorphous grey dandruff-like material on:
    • Pupillary border
    • Anterior lens surface
    • Posterior surface of iris
    • Zonules
    • Ciliary processes
  • Trabecular blockage by exfoliative material can lead to:
    • Secondary open-angle glaucoma
    • Rarely, angle-closure glaucoma
  • Other ocular symptoms may include:
    • Iris sphincter atrophy
    • Anisocoria
    • Heterochromia
  • Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.

  • Common intraocular foreign bodies:
    • Glass particles or metal chips.
  • Sites of lodgement: 
    • The anterior chamber
    • Lens
    • Posterior chamber
    • Vitreous humour
  • Consequences of lodgement: 
    • Cataract formation
    • Vitreous liquefaction
    • Retinal haemorrhages
    • Tears
    • Organic foreign bodies can cause infection.
    • Iron foreign bodies can cause siderosis.
    • Copper ones can result in chalcosis.
  • An entry wound can be identified with topical fluorescein.
  • MRI is contraindicated in metallic intraocular foreign bodies.

 

Option C.

 

Ocular trauma can be of 2 types:

  1. Closed-globe injury: can vary from simple corneal abrasions to widespread intraocular damage. A corneal abrasion highlighted with fluorescein staining is shown below.
  2. Open-globe injury: includes globe rupture or laceration.

 

 

Option D. Vossius ring is used to describe a ring-shaped pigment dispersal observed on the anterior surface of the lens due to the deposition of brown amorphous pigment granules. It is close to the constricted pupil in diameter. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, creating an impression of the iris on the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of amorphous grey dandruff-like material on various parts of the eye, leading to potential complications like secondary open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A chorionic villous sampling is done at 12 weeks in a woman whose blood group is B negative. Her husband's blood group is A positive. What is the dose of Anti D given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 50

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of Rh incompatibility, where the mother is Rh-negative (B negative) and the father is Rh-positive (A positive), there is a risk of fetal-maternal hemorrhage (FMH) during invasive procedures like chorionic villous sampling (CVS). This can lead to the mixing of fetal and maternal blood, potentially causing the mother to form antibodies against the Rh-positive fetal red blood cells. To prevent this alloimmunization, an Anti-D immunoglobulin injection is administered.

 

The standard practice is to give Anti-D immunoglobulin during any inciting event (e.g., CVS, amniocentesis, abdominal trauma, abruption, placenta previa) and at delivery. Additionally, it is given prophylactically at 28 weeks of gestation to all Rh-negative women.

 

The dosage of Anti-D depends on the gestational age:

 

 

Less than 12 weeks: 50 micrograms intramuscularly.

 

More than 12 weeks: 300 micrograms intramuscularly.

 

Since the CVS was performed at 12 weeks, the appropriate dose of Anti-D is 50 micrograms.

 

Educational objective:

 

For Rh-negative women undergoing an inciting event like chorionic villous sampling at less than 12 weeks gestation, the dose of Anti-D given is 50 micrograms.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CS sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci.

 

The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili.

 

From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteraemia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.

 

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and haemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages.

 

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Known for causing infections in immunocompromised hosts and those with chronic wounds but not typically presenting with purpuric rash and meningitis.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia: A common cause of bacterial meningitis but gram-positive and usually does not present with a purpuric rash.

 

Option D. E.coli: While it can cause meningitis in newborns and the elderly, it is not commonly associated with purpuric rash and gram-negative diplococci presentation in young adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a critical pathogen to consider in young adults presenting with symptoms of high-grade fever and a purpuric rash, especially when gram-negative diplococci are identified in the CSF. Rapid diagnosis and immediate treatment with appropriate antibiotics are crucial to prevent serious complications and mortality. This highlights the importance of vigilance for meningococcal disease in acute care settings.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for supraclavicular brachial plexus block and suddenly developed hypotension and arrhythmias. Which of the following is the first line of management? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20% IV Intralipid

 

Explanation

 

The patient experienced toxicity due to bupivacaine, a local anesthetic. The first-line treatment for local anesthetic toxicity, including bupivacaine toxicity, is the administration of 20% IV intralipid (lipid emulsion therapy). This treatment works by acting as a "lipid sink," which helps to absorb the lipophilic local anesthetic molecules and reduce their toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. IV Epinephrine: Suitable for cardiac arrest but not the first line for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Option C. IV Soda Bicarbonate: Used in cases of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity causing ventricular arrhythmias but not for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Option D. IV Dobutamine: Used to treat heart failure and certain types of shock, but not specifically for local anesthetic toxicity

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The first-line treatment for bupivacaine toxicity is the administration of 20% IV intralipid (lipid emulsion therapy).

questions.text: A pap smear taken from a patient revealed hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and low maturation index involving the whole thickness but did not breach the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysplasia

 

The hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and intact basement membrane are all suggestive of dysplasia.

 

Dysplasia is characterized by the loss in the uniformity of the individual cells and their architectural orientation.

 

The features of dysplasia include:

 

  • Pleomorphism
  • Hyperchromatic nuclei
  • High nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio
  • Increased mitotic figures

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma: In carcinoma, there is the invasion of the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Metaplasia: It refers to the replacement of one cell type with another type. It is almost always associated with tissue damage, repair, and regeneration. The most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous.

 

Option D. Hyperplasia: It refers to the increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ. It can be physiologic or pathological. Enlargement of the female breast during pregnancy is physiologic hyperplasia. Endometrial hyperplasia is an example of pathological hyperplasia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysplasia is characterized by abnormal cellular features such as pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic figures, and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. It involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without breaching the basement membrane, distinguishing it from carcinoma, which involves invasion beyond the basement membrane.

choices.text: Bath the baby with warm water immediately

questions.text: A mother delivers a 2.5 kg baby with normal vaginal delivery in a rural area. Which of the following is an incorrect statement? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bath the baby with warm water immediately

     

Newborn care practices emphasize immediate and appropriate actions to ensure the health and safety of the infant. Bathing the baby immediately after birth is discouraged because the baby's skin needs to adapt to the new environment, and the vernix (a protective layer on the skin) should be allowed to remain on the skin for as long as possible to provide a barrier against infection. Immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is generally not recommended, especially in settings where environmental conditions (such as warmth and cleanliness) are not optimal.

 

The recommended practice is to wait at least 24 hours and then start with gentle sponging until the umbilical cord falls off, typically within the first week of life. Only after this can full baths be introduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exclusive breastfeeding: This is the recommended feeding method for newborns, providing optimal nutrition and immunity support. It should be started within the first hour of birth.

 

Option C. Clean the eyes: Cleaning the eyes is a standard neonatal practice to prevent infection. This is part of routine newborn care and helps prevent neonatal conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Skin to skin contact: Skin-to-skin contact is encouraged immediately after birth as it helps regulate the newborn's body temperature, promotes bonding, and supports breastfeeding initiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended; it should be delayed until the umbilical cord falls off, and gentle sponging should be started after 24 hours to maintain hygiene and prevent hypothermia.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is primarily found in tendons?( NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Collagen

 

Explanation:


Collagen is the primary fibrous protein found in tendons, providing both structure and strength. Skin derives its strength and flexibility from an intertwined mesh of collagen and keratin fibers. More specifically, collagen is present in connective tissues such as ligaments and tendons. Collagen's elongated form and high degree of crosslinking gives it exceptional tensile strength, making it perfectly suited for tendons which must connect muscles to bones and transmit mechanical forces during movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrin: This is incorrect as fibrin is a fibrous protein involved in blood clotting, not a structural component of tendons. Fibrin forms when fibrinogen is cleaved by thrombin during the coagulation cascade.

 

Option C. Fibrillin: While fibrillin is a glycoprotein found in connective tissue, it is specifically a structural component of microfibrils that helps in elastin deposition. Mutations in fibrillin-1 cause Marfan syndrome, but it is not the primary protein in tendons.

 

Option D. Proteoglycans: Though proteoglycans are found in the extracellular matrix of various connective tissues including tendons, they are not the primary structural component of tendons. They function in hydration and resistance to compression rather than providing tensile strength.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Collagen is the principal fibrous protein in tendons, providing exceptional tensile strength due to its elongated form, triple-helical structure, and extensive crosslinking - properties that enable tendons to efficiently transfer forces between muscles and bones.

choices.text: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
Chediak-Higashi syndrome
Essential thrombocythemia

questions.text: CD-59 is involved in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

 

CD-59 is involved in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

 

PNH is an acquired red cell membrane disorder characterized by chronic intravascular hemolysis. The absence of two proteins, decay accelerating factor (DAF, CD55) and membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis (MIRL, CD59), makes RBCs overly sensitive to complement's lytic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: This is a genetic disorder affecting the immune and nervous systems, characterized by abnormalities in lysosomal trafficking, leading to abnormal neutrophil function and albinism.

 

Option C. Essential thrombocythemia: A myeloproliferative disorder characterized by the excessive production of platelets without a known cause.

 

Option D. Primary myelofibrosis: Another myeloproliferative disorder where the bone marrow is progressively replaced with fibrous tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CD-59 deficiency is specific to PNH and does not play a role in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, essential thrombocythemia, or primary myelofibrosis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with respiratory distress after a history of eating peanuts. Clinical examination reveals an audible thud during breathing. What is the most likely location of the foreign body? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trachea

 

Explanation: 

 

The foreign body is most likely in the trachea because:

 

  • Presence of audible thud during breathing is pathognomonic of tracheal foreign body
  • Foreign body in trachea moves up and down with respiration causing the thud sound
  • Peanuts are common aspirated foreign bodies in children
  • Acute presentation with respiratory distress after eating suggests aspiration
  • History of eating peanuts followed by immediate symptoms suggests aspiration pathway rather than ingestion

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Larynx

 

  • Would cause immediate severe respiratory distress
  • Stridor would be prominent
  • Voice changes would be present
  • Less likely to cause thud sound

 

Option B. Bronchus

 

  • More common final location but doesn't cause thud sound
  • Usually right main bronchus due to anatomical orientation
  • Would cause unilateral wheeze or decreased breath sounds
  • No up and down movement to cause thud

 

Option D. Oesophagus

 

  • Would cause dysphagia rather than respiratory distress
  • No audible thud during breathing
  • Drooling and inability to swallow would be prominent
  • Different management approach required

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Foreign bodies in the trachea cause biphasic stridor and audible thuds due to partial airway obstruction. Immediate intervention with bronchoscopy is required to prevent asphyxiation.

questions.text: A patient underwent endoscopy, during the procedure perforation occurred at 25 cm from the incisors. Which structure is likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arch of aorta

 

During an endoscopy, if a perforation occurs at 25 cm from the incisors, the structure most likely to be damaged is the arch of the aorta. At this anatomical level, the esophagus is in close proximity to the arch of the aorta and the left bronchus. The esophagus traverses behind the arch of the aorta around this distance from the upper incisors, making it susceptible to injury in the event of a perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diaphragm: The diaphragm is located approximately 40 cm from the incisors, much lower than the site of perforation.

 

Option C. Pharyngoesophageal junction: This junction is situated around 15 cm from the incisors, which is too high up the esophagus to be relevant to a perforation at 25 cm.

 

Option D. Right bronchus: The right bronchus is not in proximity to the esophagus at the 25 cm mark. It is the left bronchus that is close to the esophagus at this level, but it was not listed as an option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perforation at 25 cm from the incisors during endoscopy is most likely to involve the arch of the aorta due to its anatomical position relative to the esophagus.

questions.text: A patient presented with Ventricular Tachycardia. What is the best drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

Explanation

 

For treating ventricular tachycardia (VT), the drug of choice in acute situations according to Advanced Life Support (ALS) protocols is Amiodarone. It is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that works by prolonging the action potential duration and refractory period in the myocardial cells, thus stabilizing the cardiac rhythm.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Adenosine: Ineffective for ventricular tachycardia as it is primarily used for supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Option C. Propranolol: A beta-blocker used for various cardiac conditions, but not typically effective for acute VT.

 

Option D. Ivabradine: Used to reduce heart rate in chronic heart failure and stable angina, not suitable for VT management

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Amiodarone is the best drug for the acute management of ventricular tachycardia due to its efficacy in stabilizing cardiac rhythm by prolonging the action potential and refractory period in myocardial cells.

questions.text: What is Edmond Locard known for? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Theory of exchange

 

Edmond Locard discovered two principles:

 

  1. Locard's Exchange Principle It states that whenever two bodies come in contact with each other, there is exchange of material between the two and so a criminal can be linked to crime
  2. Poroscopy: It is a method of identification through the comparison of the impressions of pores of sweat glands (present on palmar and plantar surfaces).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Study of fingerprints: Sir Francis Galton, developed the first classification system for fingerprints.

 

Option C. Stature estimation: This field involves estimating an individual's height from skeletal remains.

 

Option D. Forensic ballistics: This deals with the examination of firearms, bullets, and bullet impacts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edmond Locard is best known for Locard's Exchange Principle, which states that whenever two bodies come into contact, there is an exchange of materials, thereby linking criminals to crime scenes.

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

 

The patient with given complaints points to meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae and it exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus colonies. When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus.

 

H. influenzae can grow on blood agar if the source of V factor is provided

 

When S. aureus is streaked across a blood agar plate perpendicular to the H. influenzae streak line, then factor V is released from S. aureus.

 

It forms larger colonies adjacent to S. aureus streak line and size of the colonies decreases gradually away from the S. aureus streak line, this is known as Satellitism. Therefore, used for the isolation of H. influenzae.

 

 

 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

 

  1. Factor X = hemin→ present freely in blood
  2. Factor V = Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) →present inside RBCs (also produced by some bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus)

 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and less commonly suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis.

 

DOC - Cefotaxime or ceftazidime

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bacitracin sensitive: Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes, a Gram positive coccus.

 

Option B. Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar: Associated with organisms such as Shigella, Salmonella, and Proteus species.

 

Option D. It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar: Alpha-hemolysis on blood agar is a characteristic of Streptococcus pneumonia, a gram-positive coccus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Haemophilus influenzae infection, particularly meningitis, look for satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar, indicating the organism's dependence on externally sourced V factor for growth.

choices.text: BCR ABL

questions.text: All-trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the following genetic aberrations? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PML-RARA

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), which is associated with the PML-RARA fusion gene.

 

The long arm of chromosome 17 encodes the retinoic acid alpha receptor gene (RARA). It is primarily expressed in hematopoietic cells and plays an important role in gene expression regulation. RARA is bound by the nuclear corepressor factor in the absence of retinoid acid, causing transcriptional repression. RARA is activated in the presence of retinoic acid, and promyelocytes undergo terminal differentiation.

 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is a distinct subtype of acute leukemia distinguished by abnormal promyelocyte proliferation, life-threatening coagulopathy, and the chromosome translocation t (15;17) (q22;q11-12). This results in an abnormal fusion protein known as PML-RARA, which has a low affinity for retinoids. This inhibits transcription and thus prevents gene expression for cellular differentiation. This leads to the accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells.

 

 

Rx: The condition is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA). It binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein. This causes conformational change such that the protein regains its normal function and activates DNA transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BCR-ABL: Associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

 

  • Treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib, not ATRA.

 

Option C. CMYC: Associated with Burkitt lymphoma.

 

  • Involves translocation t (8;14) affecting the c-Myc oncogene.

 

Option D. RUNX1-ETO: Associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with t (8;21).

 

  • Treated with standard chemotherapy regimens, not specifically ATRA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion gene resulting from the t(15;17) translocation. This treatment promotes the differentiation of leukemic promyelocytes, improving clinical outcomes in APL patients.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypothyroidism

 

Hypothyroidism can lead to various cardiac manifestations, including bradycardia and atrioventricular (AV) block. This is due to the metabolic effects of low thyroid hormone levels, which slow down the heart rate and can increase the risk of heart block. This type of AV block is generally reversible and often improves with appropriate thyroid hormone replacement therapy, such as levothyroxine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cushing's syndrome: Typically associated with other cardiovascular issues such as hypertension due to excessive cortisol levels, but not commonly with AV block.

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: Usually results in symptoms opposite to those of hypothyroidism, like tachycardia or atrial fibrillation, rather than AV block.

 

Option D. Pheochromocytoma: This condition, characterized by excess production of catecholamines, typically presents with episodic hypertension and tachycardia, not AV block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothyroidism causes reversible AV Block that improves with LT4 supplementation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to you with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Consolidation

 

The patient's symptoms of fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration suggest an infectious process in the lungs. The CT scan provided shows a large area of increased density (whitish patch) in the right lung, particularly in the lower lobe. This area is accompanied by air bronchograms, which are dark branching structures representing air-filled bronchi within the consolidated lung tissue. The presence of air bronchograms is a classic sign of consolidation, which indicates that the alveoli are filled with inflammatory exudates, cells, or other materials, typically due to pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mass: A mass would appear as a localized, well-defined lesion in the lung tissue without the characteristic air bronchograms seen in consolidation. It would not typically present with diffuse symptoms like those described (fever, breathlessness, and productive cough).

 

Option C. Pleural Effusion: Pleural effusion involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs. On imaging, it appears as a homogenous opacity at the lung base with a meniscus sign. It does not show air bronchograms and typically does not present with the same radiographic features as consolidation.

 

Option D. Diaphragmatic Hernia: A diaphragmatic hernia involves the protrusion of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm. This condition would appear on imaging as abdominal organs (e.g., intestines) within the chest cavity, not as a consolidation pattern with air bronchograms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consolidation in the lung, often due to pneumonia, is characterized by a homogenous area of increased density with air bronchograms on imaging, and presents with symptoms such as fever, breathlessness, and productive cough.

questions.text: A patient presents with gradual loss of night vision and peripheral vision. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these symptoms according to the given fundoscopic image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinitis Pigmentosa

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is a progressive eye disease characterized by the loss of night vision (nyctalopia) and peripheral vision, often described as "tunnel vision." The disease involves the degeneration of photoreceptor cells in the retina, primarily affecting the rods, which are responsible for low-light vision.

 

The characteristic fundoscopic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa include:

 

  1. Black pigmentary deposits (bone spicule appearance) – These are seen around the periphery of the retina.
  2. Vascular attenuation – Retinal vessels are thinned out, indicating decreased blood flow.
  3. Waxy pallor of the optic disc – This is a pale appearance of the optic disc due to retinal degeneration.

 

The fundoscopic image shows black pigmentation and attenuated vessels, which are classic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fundus flavimaculatus: This condition is a variant of Stargardt disease and primarily involves the macula, showing yellowish flecks in the retina. This condition is associated with chromosome 1 and mutations in the ABCA4 gene.

 

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhage: Retinal hemorrhage refers to bleeding within the retina, often appearing as red patches or dots. It does not cause a gradual loss of night vision or tunnel vision and is not associated with black pigmentary changes.

 

 

Option D. Fundus Albipunctatus: This condition is characterized by white, dot-like lesions scattered across the retina and may also present with night vision problems. However, it lacks the black pigmentation and vascular attenuation seen in Retinitis Pigmentosa, making it an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is identified by a triad of symptoms: black pigmentary deposits, vascular attenuation, and waxy pallor of the optic disc, accompanied by nyctalopia and tunnel vision.

questions.text:
First part of PCT has which of the following transport proteins? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Sodium potassium pump
  2. Na- glucose co-transporter
  3. Sodium hydrogen antiport
  4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1,2,3

 

1. Sodium-potassium pump: This transporter is found on the basolateral side of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) cells and is critical for maintaining the sodium gradient that drives other transport processes.

 

2. Na-glucose co-transporter: This is located on the apical membrane of PCT cells and uses the sodium gradient to co-transport glucose from the tubular lumen into the cell.

 

3. Sodium-hydrogen antiport: Also on the apical membrane, this antiporter exchanges sodium from the tubular lumen with hydrogen ions from the cell, playing a key role in sodium reabsorption and pH balance.

 

Other Option

 

4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter: It is present in the distal or late part of PCT (Not in the early PCT)- contributes to bicarbonate reabsorption.

The correct combination based on the provided answer is b) 1,2,3, which includes the sodium-potassium pump, the Na-glucose co-transporter, and the sodium-hydrogen antiport, all of which are essential for the function of the PCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proximal convoluted tubule – transport processes –

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orgasm

 

This phase involves the release of sexual tension. Premature ejaculation and anorgasmia are disorders of this phase.

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It involves ejaculation that occurs earlier than desired, often with minimal sexual stimulation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Desire: This phase refers to the interest in engaging in sexual activity. Disorders of this phase might manifest as hypoactive sexual desire disorder or sexual aversion disorder.

 

Option B. Arousal: This phase is characterized by physiological changes such as erection in men and vaginal lubrication in women. Erectile dysfunction is a disorder of this phase in men.

 

Option D. Pain: This isn't a phase of the sexual response cycle. However, dyspareunia refers to pain during intercourse and can be a clinical condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It is characterized by a pattern of persistent or recurrent ejaculation with minimal sexual stimulation before or immediately after the vaginal penetration.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 579.

questions.text: In what proportion of cases is a complete vesicular mole found to be associated with Theca lutein cysts? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Between 20% and 30%

 

Theca lutein cysts are a common finding in complete vesicular mole cases, occurring in approximately 25-30% of patients. These ovarian cysts form due to excessive production of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which stimulates the ovaries. In complete molar pregnancy, the significantly elevated hCG levels lead to ovarian hyperstimulation, resulting in these characteristic bilateral cysts which regress spontaneously within 2 months after expulsion of the mole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Less than 5%: This percentage is significantly lower than the actual occurrence. This figure is closer to the rate at which partial moles progress to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (1-5%).

 

Option B. Between 5% and 15%: This range is too low for complete molar pregnancies. The actual incidence is higher at 25-30%.

 

Option D. Between 50% and 60%: This percentage is higher than what is specifically mentioned for complete moles. While overall in hydatidiform moles, bilateral lutein cysts may be present in "about 50%," the more specific figure for complete moles is 25-30%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complete molar pregnancies are associated with theca lutein cysts in approximately 25-30% of cases due to excessive hCG production, which provides an important clinical sign when evaluating suspected gestational trophoblastic disease.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male, previously diagnosed with a psychiatric disorder, has become aggressive with his neighbors, is speaking rapidly, and is sleeping very little. He also exhibits hyperactive behavior after discontinuing his prescribed medication. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bipolar disorder (manic episode)

 

The patient presents with classical symptoms of a manic episode, which is a characteristic feature of bipolar disorder.

 

  • Speaking rapidly 
  • Decreased sleep (characteristic reduced need for sleep in mania)
  • Hyperactivity (increased psychomotor activity)
  • Aggression (can occur due to irritability/dysphoria in mania)

 

These symptoms appeared after discontinuing medication, suggesting a recurrence of a previously diagnosed bipolar disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Depression: Incorrect because depression presents with opposite symptoms like low mood, decreased activity, and social withdrawal rather than hyperactivity and aggression.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: Incorrect because schizophrenia primarily presents with delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized behavior. While aggression can occur, rapid speech and decreased sleep needs are not characteristic features.

 

Option D. Substance-induced mood disorder: Incorrect because the symptoms appeared after discontinuing medication rather than due to substance use. The temporal relationship with medication discontinuation suggests underlying bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic presentation of a manic episode: rapid speech, decreased need for sleep, hyperactivity, and aggressive behavior, especially in context of medication discontinuation in a previously diagnosed psychiatric patient.

 

Symptoms of Mania

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with substernal chest discomfort. On examination, he was hypotensive, drowsy, and had unequal pulses. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this situation to ascertain the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trans-esophageal echocardiography

 

The presentation of acute chest pain, hypotension, drowsiness, and unequal pulses strongly suggests aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate diagnosis and management.

 

Trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is highly sensitive and specific for diagnosing aortic dissection. It can be performed at the bedside, making it ideal for unstable patients. TEE provides detailed images of the aorta and can quickly confirm the presence of an intimal flap, a characteristic finding in aortic dissection.

 

If the patient has been stable, then preferred investigation of choice is CT angiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CXR PA view: A chest X-ray (CXR) might show a widened mediastinum, which can be a clue to aortic dissection, but it is not definitive. It lacks the sensitivity and specificity needed for a rapid and accurate diagnosis in an emergency setting.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide excellent detail, it is not suitable for acutely unstable patients due to the time required for the scan and the need to transport the patient to the MRI suite. It is not practical in an emergency setting.

 

Option D. Troponin assay: Troponin assays are used to diagnose myocardial infarction, not aortic dissection. Although troponins can be elevated in some cases of aortic dissection, they do not provide definitive diagnostic information about the dissection itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of suspected aortic dissection, especially in an unstable patient, trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the best diagnostic tool due to its high sensitivity and ability to be performed at the bedside, providing rapid and accurate confirmation of the diagnosis.

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is due to which of the following vitamin deficiencies? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

 

Laryngismus stridulus, also known as laryngospasm, is a condition characterized by a sudden and involuntary contraction of the vocal cords, which can lead to difficulty in breathing and a high-pitched sound known as stridor. This condition is often associated with hypocalcemia, which can be a consequence of Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Vitamin D plays a crucial role in calcium homeostasis by promoting calcium absorption in the gut. A deficiency in Vitamin D leads to decreased calcium levels in the blood, which can trigger neuromuscular excitability and result in laryngospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency typically leads to neurological problems due to oxidative stress but is not associated with laryngospasm or hypocalcemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision (night blindness) and the immune system. It does not cause laryngospasm.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums, bruising, and poor wound healing, but not laryngospasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngismus stridulus (laryngospasm) can be caused by hypocalcemia, which is often a result of Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with anemia and hemoglobinuria. Investigations reveal increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following physical examination findings can support the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mechanical second heart sound

 

The above scenario, which includes anemia, increased LDH, and hemoglobinuria, as well as schistocytes on a peripheral smear, is suggestive of angiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) caused by red cell trauma. A mechanical second heart sound can help to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a type of hemolytic anemia caused by red cell trauma.

 

Shear forces cause hemolysis in artificial mechanical cardiac valves due to turbulent blood flow and pressure gradients. This traumatic damage causes intravascular hemolysis and the appearance in blood smears of red cell fragments (schistocytes), burr cells, helmet cells, and triangle cells. The same pressure gradients are also responsible for a mechanical heart sound on auscultation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenomegaly: Splenomegaly is often seen in various hemolytic anemias but is not specific for MAHA associated with mechanical heart valves.

 

Option B. Frontal bossing: Frontal bossing is seen in congenital hemolytic anemias such as thalassemia and sickle cell anemia due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, but not typically in MAHA.

 

Option D. Goitre: Goitre is related to thyroid disorders and is not associated with hemolytic anemia or mechanical heart valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with anemia, hemoglobinuria, increased LDH, and schistocytes on a peripheral smear, the presence of a mechanical second heart sound can support the diagnosis of angiopathic hemolytic anemia due to mechanical heart valves. The mechanical destruction of red blood cells leads to intravascular hemolysis, characteristic laboratory findings, and specific physical examination findings related to the heart valve.

questions.text: Calcitonin levels are increased in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperparathyroidism

 

Calcitonin, a hormone secreted by the thyroid gland, is involved in the regulation of calcium levels in the body. In conditions where there is an increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, such as in hyperparathyroidism, there is a corresponding increase in blood calcium levels. The body responds to this hypercalcemia by increasing the secretion of calcitonin to help lower the calcium levels back to normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: While hyperthyroidism involves the thyroid gland, it does not typically result in increased calcitonin levels. Hyperthyroidism mainly increases thyroid hormones like thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), not calcitonin.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition is characterized by decreased PTH levels, leading to hypocalcemia (low calcium levels), not hypercalcemia that would stimulate calcitonin production.

 

Option D. Cushing's syndrome: Cushing's syndrome involves an excess of cortisol, a steroid hormone, and does not directly affect calcitonin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased calcitonin levels are typically seen in response to hypercalcemia, as seen in hyperparathyroidism. This is a compensatory mechanism to help maintain calcium homeostasis.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lecithin

 

Specifically phosphatidylcholine, is a major component of pulmonary surfactant. Surfactant plays a crucial role in reducing surface tension in the alveoli of the lungs, preventing their collapse. A deficiency in lecithin can contribute to respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cephalin: Cephalin is a type of phospholipid, and while it is present in cell membranes, it is not a major component of pulmonary surfactant and is not directly associated with respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option B. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is another type of phospholipid found in cell membranes. The deficiency to recycle this lipid due to defective lysosomal enzyme sphingomyelinase cause sphingolipidoses also known as Niemann Pick disease.

 

Option D. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is a phospholipid found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and bacterial membranes. The disease associated with cardiolipins are anti-phospholipid syndrome and Barth syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDS is a common condition in premature infants due to inadequate surfactant production, particularly the deficiency of lecithin. The educational objective is to understand the etiology of RDS and its association with surfactant components, specifically lecithin. This knowledge is crucial for healthcare professionals involved in the care of neonates, as RDS can have serious respiratory consequences in premature infants and requires appropriate management and support.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis is not responding well to conventional treatment. Her rheumatologist is considering adding tocilizumab to her treatment regimen. Which of the following interleukins (IL) is primarily targeted by tocilizumab? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IL-6

 

  • Tocilizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets and inhibits the interleukin-6 (IL-6) receptor. By blocking the IL-6 receptor, tocilizumab interrupts the signaling pathway of IL-6, a cytokine involved in the inflammatory response. This is particularly beneficial in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, where elevated levels of IL-6 contribute to the inflammatory process.
  • Tocilizumab has also been used in COVID-19 for cytokine release syndrome.
  • It is avoided in patients with liver disease, immunosuppression, having a high risk of GIT perforation, Absolute Neutrophil Count <500 cell/µl and Platelet count <50000 cells/µl.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IL-2: Drugs like basiliximab or daclizumab are used to target IL-2 receptors.

 

Option C. IL-4: Dupilumab is an example of a medication that targets IL-4.

 

Option D. IL-5: Mepolizumab and reslizumab are examples of medications that target IL-5.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tocilizumab targets the IL-6 receptor, making it effective for managing rheumatoid arthritis and certain other inflammatory conditions by inhibiting the IL-6 signaling pathway.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the point from A to C in the given flowchart depicting the natural history of a disease? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lead time

 

Lead time is defined as the interval between the point a condition is detected through screening and the Time it would normally have been detected due to appearance and reporting of signs and symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening time:  This term refers to the period during which screening tests are conducted to detect disease in asymptomatic individuals.

 

Option C. Lag time:  This term is generally used to describe a delay between the onset of an event and its detection or measurement. In the context of disease, lag time could refer to the delay between symptom onset and diagnosis.

 

Option D. Generation time:  This term is typically used in epidemiology to describe the time interval between the infection of a host and the subsequent transmission of the disease to another host. It does not relate to the timeline of diagnosis within an individual patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead time is the interval between the detection of a disease through screening and its usual time of diagnosis due to symptom presentation.

 

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening (leading the time of diagnosis)

 

Early detection of disease due to screening (B rather than C) will ensure earlier institution of treatment, thus better prognosis.

questions.text: First line of treatment for glaucoma in adults is:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PG analogues

 

These are typically the first choice for the long-term management of glaucoma due to their efficacy and favourable patient adherence factors.

 

Prostaglandin analogues are a class of medications used as the first-line treatment for glaucoma. They work by increasing the outflow of the aqueous humor from the eye, which lowers intraocular pressure. These drugs are preferred due to their effectiveness and once-daily dosing, which improves patient compliance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atropine: is a muscarinic antagonist and is not used for the treatment of glaucoma. It dilates the pupil, which can potentially worsen glaucoma, especially angle-closure glaucoma, by blocking the drainage of the aqueous humor from the eye.

 

Option C. Acetazolamide: is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces the production of aqueous humor in the eye, thereby reducing intraocular pressure. It is not typically the first-line treatment due to the potential for systemic side effects and the presence of more effective topical treatments.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: is a cholinergic agonist that contracts the ciliary muscle and opens the trabecular meshwork, allowing for increased outflow of aqueous humor. It is not usually the first choice for the chronic treatment of glaucoma due to its frequent dosing and side effects but can be used in acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for adult glaucoma is Prostaglandin Analogues, which are effective in lowering intraocular pressure with a convenient dosing schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

 

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. JC virus: Incorrect, while JC virus can cause infections in transplant recipients, its occurrence is less frequent compared to CMV during this specific post-transplant period.

 

Option C. BK virus: Incorrect, although BK virus is a concern in renal transplant patients, particularly for its role in causing nephropathy, it is not as predominant as CMV in the early months following transplantation.

 

Option D. Epstein-Barr virus: Incorrect, Epstein-Barr virus also poses a risk for post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorders in transplant recipients, but it is less commonly the primary pathogen within the first few months post-transplant compared to CMV.

 

Educational Objective:


Cytomegalovirus is the leading cause of infection in renal transplant recipients during the first four months post-transplantation, showcasing the importance of monitoring and managing CMV to prevent its common presentations and complications in this vulnerable period.

questions.text: Identify the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroid


The image shows a well-circumscribed, whitish lesion within the uterine cavity, which is characteristic of a submucosal fibroid. Fibroids, also known as leiomyomas, are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus. They can present as distinct, well-defined lesions that are separate from the normal myometrial tissue, often appearing white or light in color compared to the surrounding pink myometrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Adenomyosis:  is incorrect because adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, leading to a uniformly enlarged and diffusely thickened uterus without distinct, well-defined lesions.

 

Option C. Endometrial polyp:  is incorrect as polyps are usually small, soft, and protruding growths that arise from the endometrial lining. They do not appear as a well-defined, firm, and large mass like the fibroid shown.

 

Option D. Endometrial cancer: is incorrect because endometrial cancer typically presents as irregular, vascular, and possibly friable growths within the uterine cavity, not as a smooth, well-defined mass.

 

Educational Objective:


Fibroids are well-defined, circumscribed lesions within the uterine cavity that are distinct in color and structure compared to surrounding myometrial tissue, distinguishing them from other uterine conditions like adenomyosis, polyps, and cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following assays is not typically used for the estimation of total serum protein? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bromocresol green

 

Explanation:

 

Bromcresol green is not typically used for estimation of total serum protein. Instead, it is a dye specifically used for the determination of albumin in serum. Bromcresol green binds selectively to albumin, forming a colored complex that can be measured spectrophotometrically. This makes it valuable for assessing albumin levels but unsuitable for measuring total protein content, which includes many different proteins beyond just albumin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biuret: This is incorrectly identified as a wrong answer. The Biuret test is a standard method for total protein estimation. It produces a purple color when the reagent (copper sulfate in an alkaline solution) reacts with peptide bonds. The Biuret test requires a minimum of two peptide bonds for a positive result, making it suitable for detecting tripeptides and proteins.

 

Option B. Bradford: This is incorrectly identified as a wrong answer. The Bradford assay uses Coomassie Brilliant Blue dye which binds to proteins, particularly basic amino acid residues. It is commonly used for total protein estimation due to its sensitivity and reliability.

 

Option C. Lowry's: This is incorrectly identified as a wrong answer. The Lowry method combines the Biuret reaction with the reduction of Folin-Ciocalteu reagent, which produces a blue color. It is a widely used and sensitive method for measuring total protein concentration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While Biuret, Bradford, and Lowry's methods are commonly used for total protein estimation through different molecular interactions with proteins, bromcresol green is specific for albumin determination and cannot measure the diverse spectrum of proteins present in serum.

questions.text: Which lymphoma is strongly associated with overexpression of BCL2? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

 

Follicular lymphoma is associated with overexpression of BCL2.

 

Normal cells include the BCL2 gene, however this gene's mutant version with the recognizable translocation t (14;18) (q32; q21) was originally identified in B-cell lymphoma, hence the term BCL.

 

Numerous other human malignancies, including those of the breast, thyroid, and prostate, also exhibit it.

 

Due to a mutation in the BCL2 gene, more living cells are undergoing mitosis, which contributes to the formation of tumors by removing the apoptosis-inhibitory control on cancer cells.

 

The most prevalent chromosomal translocation in human lymphomas, the t(14;18)  (q32;q21) is found in up to 30% of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas and over 85% of follicular lymphomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burkitt lymphoma: Characterized by the c-MYC gene translocation, not BCL2 overexpression.

 

Option C. Diffuse large-cell lymphoma: While BCL2 can be overexpressed due to the same translocation, it is more typically associated with follicular lymphoma.

 

Option D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL): CLL can also exhibit overexpression of BCL2, but this is generally due to other genetic mechanisms rather than the t(14;18) translocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma is primarily associated with the overexpression of BCL2 due to the t(14;18) chromosomal translocation. This genetic alteration is a critical factor in the pathogenesis of follicular lymphoma, enabling lymphoma cells to evade apoptosis and sustain tumor growth. Understanding the role of BCL2 in various lymphomas helps in differentiating among them and tailoring appropriate therapeutic strategies.

questions.text: Bleeding gums are seen in which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

Scurvy is a condition caused by a deficiency in Vitamin C (ascorbic acid). Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, which is crucial for maintaining the integrity of connective tissues, including gums. A deficiency in Vitamin C leads to weakened blood vessels, resulting in symptoms such as bleeding gums, easy bruising, and poor wound healing. The classic symptom of scurvy, bleeding gums, is a direct result of impaired collagen synthesis and capillary fragility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickets: Rickets is caused by Vitamin D deficiency, leading to weakened and soft bones. Symptoms include skeletal deformities such as bowed legs and thickened wrists and ankles, but bleeding gums are not a typical feature of rickets.

 

Option C. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta, also known as brittle bone disease, is a genetic disorder characterized by fragile bones that break easily. It primarily affects bone health and does not typically cause bleeding gums.

 

Option D. Hartnup disorder: Hartnup disorder is a rare genetic condition that impairs the body's ability to absorb certain amino acids from the diet, leading to symptoms like skin rashes and neurological issues. Bleeding gums are not a characteristic symptom of Hartnup disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleeding gums are a classic symptom of scurvy, which is caused by a deficiency in Vitamin C.

choices.text: Rosette cataract with control of blood sugar level
Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient complaints of blurring of vision and gives history of Diabetes for the past 10 years. On examination findings as shown in image were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis and treatment for the same. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

 

Immature cataract refers to a cataract that has not yet progressed to cause complete opacity and loss of vision. Phacoemulsification is a modern cataract surgery technique that uses ultrasonic vibrations to emulsify the lens, allowing for its removal and replacement with an IOL. This is a common treatment for cataracts that are significantly affecting vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sunflower Cataract with Lens Extraction: Sunflower cataract is characterized by the presence of a central, sunflower-like opacity on the lens. It is commonly associated with conditions such as Wilson's disease, where copper deposits on the lens. Treatment typically involves surgical removal of the cataractous lens (lens extraction), often followed by the implantation of an artificial intraocular lens (IOL).

 

Option B. Rosette Cataract with Control of Blood Sugar Level: A rosette cataract usually forms a star-shaped pattern and is often associated with trauma. While controlling blood sugar levels is essential for patients with diabetes to prevent the progression of diabetic retinopathy and other complications, it may not reverse the changes already present in the lens.

 

Option D. Zonular Cataract with Lensectomy: Zonular cataract refers to the opacities that affect the zone or region of the lens. A lensectomy involves the surgical removal of the lens, which can be applied to different types of cataracts, often followed by the placement of an IOL.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The diagnosis of cataracts involves a thorough examination of the lens using slit-lamp microscopy or similar diagnostic tools. Understanding the underlying causes, such as diabetes, and recognizing the specific patterns associated with different types of cataracts are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment, which often involves surgery to restore vision. Regular monitoring and management of blood sugar levels are essential in diabetic patients to prevent or slow the progression of diabetic cataracts.

questions.text: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is caused by: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occult filariasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia (TPE) is classified under "Pulmonary Infiltrates With Eosinophilia." It represents a hypersensitivity response to filarial parasites, specifically Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi. The condition is characterized by peripheral eosinophilia, elevated IgE levels, and pulmonary infiltrates, typically occurring in endemic regions for filariasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebral malaria: This is a severe complication of Plasmodium falciparum infection affecting the central nervous system. It has no relationship with pulmonary eosinophilia or the pathophysiology of TPE.

 

Option C. Pneumonic plague: This is caused by Yersinia pestis and presents as an acute infectious pneumonia with high fever, productive cough, and hemoptysis, without the characteristic eosinophilia seen in TPE.

 

Option D. Asthmatic bronchitis: While asthma can be associated with eosinophilia (such as in EGPA/Churg-Strauss syndrome), it is not the cause of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia, which is specifically related to filarial infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia is a manifestation of occult filariasis, characterized by pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia, and is distinct from other eosinophilic lung diseases like ABPA, Löffler's syndrome, and EGPA.

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Falciform ligament

 

The structure marked A is ventral mesogastrium. The falciform ligament is a derivative of the ventral mesogastrium.

 

 

  • Mesogastriumis double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ (stomach) and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.
  • The ventral mesogastrium: is a structure found only in the foregut and is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum.
  • It is derived from the septum transversum and is divided into two parts by the growth of the liver into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum.
  • These two parts are the lesser omentum, which extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver, and the ligaments of the liver, which include all the liver ligaments except for the ligamentum teres.
  • The Dorsal mesogastrium: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut are connected to the posterior abdominal wall by the Dorsal mesogastrium.
  • The dorsal mesentery extends from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut and has specific names depending on the region it is found in.
    • Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach
    • Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum
    • Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum
    • Mesoappendix- appendix
    • Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrosplenic Ligament: It is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It's a peritoneal fold that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. The short gastric vessels and the left gastroepiploic vessels run within this ligament.

 

Option B. Lienorenal Ligament: It is also derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney. As with the gastrosplenic ligament, it's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum.

 

Option D. Gastrophrenic Ligament: it is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It is the portion of the greater omentum (which also has its origins in the dorsal mesogastrium) that attaches the stomach to the diaphragm. It's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Falciform Ligament is derived from the ventral mesogastrium. This sickle-shaped ligament runs from the anterior abdominal wall to the liver, effectively connecting the liver to the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall. The ligamentum teres (remnant of the umbilical vein) runs within the free edge of this ligament.

questions.text: The effects of cholera toxin are mediated through which of the following second messengers? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. cAMP

 

Explanation:

 

Cholera toxin mediates its effects through cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) as the second messenger. The toxin consists of A and B subunits, where the B subunit binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells, allowing the entry of the A subunit. Once inside the cell, fragment A activates adenylate cyclase, resulting in increased intracellular cAMP levels. Elevated cAMP then activates protein kinase A, which phosphorylates the CFTR chloride channels, leading to massive secretion of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen while inhibiting sodium absorption. This mechanism is responsible for the characteristic profuse watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. cGMP - This is incorrect because cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) is not the primary second messenger involved in cholera toxin's mechanism of action. While cGMP is an important second messenger in other systems (particularly in smooth muscle relaxation and visual signal transduction), it is not the pathway utilized by cholera toxin.

 

Option C. Ca²⁺-calmodulin - This is incorrect because calcium-calmodulin signaling is not the primary mechanism used by cholera toxin. Calcium as a second messenger is involved in many cellular processes including muscle contraction and neurotransmitter release, but cholera toxin specifically targets the cAMP pathway.

 

Option D. IP3/DAG - This is incorrect because inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG) signaling pathway is not utilized by cholera toxin. The IP3/DAG pathway is typically activated by G protein-coupled receptors linked to phospholipase C, resulting in calcium release from intracellular stores, but this is not how cholera toxin exerts its effects.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cholera toxin causes profuse secretory diarrhea by increasing intracellular cAMP levels through ADP-ribosylation of G proteins, which leads to constitutive activation of adenylate cyclase and subsequent massive fluid secretion into the intestinal lumen.

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is typically associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid hyperplasia 

 

MEN1 syndrome is characterized by a predisposition to tumors of the parathyroids, pituitary gland, and pancreatic islet cells. Parathyroid hyperplasia is the most common feature, leading to primary hyperparathyroidism in the majority of patients with MEN1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytomas are more commonly associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), not MEN1. They are tumors of the adrenal medulla that can secrete excess catecholamines.

 

Option C. Pancreatic carcinoma: While patients with MEN1 can develop various tumors in the pancreas, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors are more characteristic than pancreatic carcinoma, which is a malignancy of the exocrine pancreas.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma is associated with MEN2 syndrome, particularly MEN2A and MEN2B, and not with MEN1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hyperplasia is a hallmark of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome, often leading to primary hyperparathyroidism, and distinguish it from other conditions associated with MEN2.

questions.text: Which vitamin can be deficient in a patient who has undergone gastrectomy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency commonly occurs in patients who have undergone a gastrectomy because the parietal cells of the stomach, which produce intrinsic factor, are removed or significantly reduced. Intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. Without intrinsic factor, vitamin B12 cannot form the necessary complex to be absorbed, leading to deficiency. Conditions such as atrophic gastritis, pernicious anemia, and autoimmune diseases that affect intrinsic factor can also result in similar deficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is usually associated with malabsorption syndromes affecting fat absorption, not specifically with gastrectomy.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C absorption occurs primarily in the small intestine and is not directly affected by the absence of the stomach.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D absorption occurs in the small intestine and depends on fat absorption, which is generally not impacted by gastrectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrectomy can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency due to the loss of intrinsic factor produced by the stomach's parietal cells, which is essential for B12 absorption in the ileum.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with RTA history having thoracic and abdominal injury and showing signs of hypovolemic shock. What could be the most probable reason in decrease cardiac output in this person? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased preload

 

In the context of hypovolemic shock, which is characterized by a significant loss of blood or fluids, the most probable reason for decreased cardiac output is decreased preload. Preload refers to the volume of blood returning to the heart (venous return). A decrease in preload means that less blood is available to fill the heart during diastole, resulting in reduced ventricular filling.

 

According to the Frank-Starling law, the force of the heart's contraction is directly related to the volume of blood filling the heart (preload). If preload decreases, the force of contraction decreases, leading to a reduction in stroke volume (the amount of blood ejected with each heartbeat). Consequently, decreased stroke volume results in decreased cardiac output (the total volume of blood pumped by the heart per minute).

 

In this patient, hypovolemic shock due to thoracic and abdominal injuries would lead to significant blood loss, reducing preload and thus decreasing cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased preload: This would result in increased ventricular filling and, according to the Frank-Starling mechanism, an increase in stroke volume and cardiac output. It is not consistent with hypovolemic shock, which involves decreased blood volume.

 

Option C. Increased stroke volume: If stroke volume were increased, cardiac output would also increase. This is not consistent with the scenario of hypovolemic shock, where stroke volume and cardiac output are decreased.

 

Option D. Decreased contractility of heart: This would imply a problem with the heart muscle's ability to contract, which is not indicated in this scenario. The issue here is primarily related to blood volume (preload), not the contractile function of the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypovolemic shock, decreased preload due to significant blood or fluid loss is the primary reason for decreased cardiac output. Understanding the relationship between preload, stroke volume, and cardiac output is crucial in managing patients with shock.

questions.text: Which one of these is not used for body fat evaluation? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Breslow index 

 

  • The Breslow index is a measurement used specifically in dermatology to determine the depth of melanoma, a type of skin cancer. 
  • It measures the thickness of the tumor and is critical for staging the cancer and determining treatment and prognosis. Therefore, it is not related to the assessment of body fat or overall body composition.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Quetelet's index:  This is another name for the Body Mass Index (BMI), which is widely used to estimate body fat based on an individual's weight and height. It provides a useful general indicator of health risks associated with body fat levels.
 

Option B. Total body potassium: This measure is used to estimate body cell mass and, indirectly, muscle mass, since potassium is primarily found in muscle tissue. Total body potassium can be an indicator of body composition, including body fat.
 

Option C. Total body water: This is used to assess hydration status and body composition. The amount of water in the body can be indicative of muscle mass (which holds a high water content) compared to fat (which holds less), thus providing insights into body fat levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Breslow index assesses the depth of melanoma skin cancer. It is crucial to recognize that this index serves a specific purpose in clinical dermatology and oncology, unrelated to nutritional or fitness assessments.

 

Obesity indices are –

 

  • Broca’s Index: Ideal Body Weight (kg) = Height (cm) – 100
  • Quetelet’s Index (Body Mass Index /BMI): BMI = Weight (kg) / Height (m)2
  • Corpulence Index (CI) = Actual weight/Desirable weight
  • Ponderal Index (PI)

choices.text: To prevent teratogenic effects
To avoid failure of ATT
Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism
Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with tuberculosis and is about to begin antitubercular therapy (ATT) that includes rifampicin. She is currently taking oral contraceptives (OCP) for birth control. The clinician advises her to use an additional barrier method of contraception while undergoing treatment. What is the primary reason for this recommendation? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

 

Rifampicin is used as one of the first line drugs against tuberculosis. Rifampicin is an enzyme inducer, that induces the cytochrome P450 enzymes. Therefore, this leads to increased rate of metabolism of the OCPs, thereby leading to contraceptive failure. So, in a female receiving ATT, it is advised to use additional barrier methods of contraception apart from OCPs.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. To prevent teratogenic effects: Most of the antitubercular drugs including rifampicin, isoniazid and ethambutol are safe in pregnancy. Further she is already taking OCPs, so the examiner does not want to ask about teratogenic effect of antitubercular drugs.

 

Option B. To avoid failure of ATT: The interaction between ATT and OCP does not lead to the failure of antitubercular therapy; rather, it affects the efficacy of the oral contraceptive method.

 

Option C. Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism: This is incorrect because rifampicin actually induces, rather than decreases, the metabolism of oral contraceptives. This can lead to reduced levels of contraceptive hormones in the blood, thereby potentially leading to contraceptive failure.

 

Educational Objective

 

Rifampicin is known to induce hepatic enzymes that speed up the metabolism of various drugs, including oral contraceptives. This can lead to lower blood levels of the hormones in OCPs, thereby reducing their efficacy and increasing the risk of contraceptive failure. Hence, it is advised for patients on both medications to use an additional barrier method of contraception.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with normal bone mineral density. X-ray is given below. Identify the diagnosis: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

SCURVY

 

  • It is the deficiency of vitamin C, causing defect in the osteoid formation. 
  • The rosary found in this condition is sharp and tender. 
  • Radiological Features: 
    • Sclerosed Margins of Epiphysis
    • Osteopenia – ground glass appearance – 1st sign – thinning of cortex (pencil thin cortex).
    • Metaphysis maybe deformed or fractured.
    • Frankel’s line (zone of provisional calcification increases in width and opacity) due to failure of resorption of calcified cartilage and stands out compared to the severely osteopenic metaphysis.
    • Scurvy line or scorbutic zone (Trummerfeld’s zone) – radiolucent transverse band adjacent to the dense provisional zone.
    • Margins of the epiphysis appears sclerotic, termed as ringing of epiphyses or Wimberger’s sign (Ring sign).
    • Lateral metaphyseal spur (Pelkan spur) at ends of metaphysis is produced by outward projection of zone of provisional calcification and periosteal reaction.
    • Corner or angle sign is peripheral metaphyseal cleft.
    • Subperiosteal hemorrhage in lower end of femur and tibia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickets. In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones. There is irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis, and thin and weak new trabeculae. On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped. The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance); and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.
