Option C. Osteopetrosis. Also called as marble bone disease, it is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen. 

 

 

 

Option D. Metaphyseal dysplasia. Also known as Pyle disease, it is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by flaring of the ends of long bones with relative constriction and sclerosis of the diaphysis and mild cranial sclerosis. The flared metaphyses are relatively lucent. The patients are often asymptomatic, although genu valgus deformity may be a feature. Patients present with short-limb dwarfism characterized by coxa vara, and spinal abnormalities. Radiographs reveals bulbous expansion of metaphysis. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image in the question is suggestive of features due to vitamin C deficiency, scurvy. 
  • Following are the features seen in a patient with scurvy on a plain radiograph:

questions.text: Dose for a new drug is assessed in which phase of Clinical trial? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Phase 1

 

Phase 1: This phase involves testing the drug on a small number of healthy human volunteers. The primary objective is to evaluate the drug's safety profile, non-toxicity, and determine the appropriate dosage range. Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) is often calculated in this phase, which makes it crucial for dose assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phase 2: Phase 2 clinical trials are designed to assess the efficacy of a drug or treatment. These trials involve a larger group of participants (100) than Phase 1 and aim to provide preliminary data on whether the drug works in people who have a certain condition or disease. Phase 2 trials also continue to monitor the drug's safety and side effects.

 

Option C. Phase 3: Phase 3 trials are conducted on a larger scale to confirm the drug's efficacy, monitor side effects, compare it to commonly used treatments, and collect information that will allow the drug to be used safely. These trials involve a larger number of participants and provide the critical data needed for regulatory approval. Drugs launched post this phase.

 

Option D. Phase 4: Phase 4 trials occur after the drug has been approved for use by the FDA. These post-marketing studies monitor the long-term effectiveness and impact on the general population, including any rare or long-term side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which part of the placenta is attached to the maternal side? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decidua basalis

 

Explanation

 

The decidua is the modified endometrium of the uterus that forms in preparation for and during pregnancy. It plays a crucial role in the implantation and support of the developing fetus.

 

Decidua Basalis: This is the part of the decidua that lies directly beneath the implanted embryo and forms the maternal part of the placenta. It is the region where the trophoblasts invade to establish the placental attachment to the maternal endometrium. It supports the exchange of nutrients and waste products between the mother and the fetus.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Decidua Parietalis: This is the part of the decidua that lines the remainder of the uterine cavity that is not involved in the implantation site. It is essentially the peripheral part of the endometrium.

 

Option C. Decidua Capsularis: This part of the decidua surrounds the embryo and eventually fuses with the decidua parietalis as the embryo grows, obliterating the uterine cavity.

 

Option D. Chorionic Plate: This is the fetal side of the placenta, consisting of the chorionic villi and other fetal tissues. It is not part of the maternal endometrium.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The decidua basalis is the part of the decidua that attaches to the maternal side of the placenta, facilitating the exchange of nutrients and waste between the mother and the fetus.
  • The decidua has three distinct regions based on their location and function in relation to the implanted embryo.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is most likely affected here ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Interossei and lumbricals

 

  • Damage to the ulnar nerve can lead to weakness or atrophy of the lumbrical and interossei muscles in the hand.
  • These muscles play a crucial role in flexing the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extending the interphalangeal (IP) joints through their attachment to the dorsal digital expansions.
  • As a result of the nerve injury, the MCP joints may become extended, while the IP joints may become flexed.

 

Note: The ulnar nerve innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the hand, except for

 

  • First and second lumbrical
  • Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Opponens pollicis
  • Part of flexor pollicis brevis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor digitorum: This muscle originates from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and inserts into the dorsal digital expansions of the medial four fingers.

 

  • It acts primarily to extend the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and interphalangeal (IP) joints of the fingers.
  • If the extensor digitorum were affected, you would expect difficulty in extending the MCP and IP joints.

 

Option C. Abductor pollicis: 

  • It refers to two muscles, the abductor pollicis longus (located in the forearm) and abductor pollicis brevis (intrinsic hand muscle) whose primary function is to abduct the thumb. Dysfunction would primarily impact thumb movements and would not lead to the clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis brevis: 

  • It is one of the thenar muscles of the hand and plays a key role in thumb movement, especially in its abduction. Like the abductor pollicis longus, an issue with this muscle would impact thumb movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interossei and lumbricals are the intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

  • The lumbricals arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. They act to flex the MCP joints and extend both the proximal and distal IP joints.
  • The interossei (both dorsal and palmar) act to abduct (DAB - Dorsal Abduct) and adduct (PAD - Palmar Adduct) the fingers at the MCP joints and assist the lumbricals in flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints.
  • If these muscles are affected, as indicated in the clinical picture, there would be an extension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints (due to unopposed action of extrinsic flexors and extensors).

questions.text: Most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gestational thrombocytopenia

 

Gestational thrombocytopenia is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy. It is generally a benign condition associated with mild thrombocytopenia, where platelet counts typically range between 100,000 to 150,000 per microliter. It is not linked to adverse pregnancy outcomes and usually resolves spontaneously after delivery. The exact cause is not well understood, but it is believed to be related to the normal hemodilution and increased platelet turnover during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ITP (Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura): While ITP can cause thrombocytopenia in pregnancy, it is less common than gestational thrombocytopenia. ITP involves an autoimmune response leading to severe platelet destruction.

 

Option C. HELLP syndrome: HELLP syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia that includes hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets. While it causes thrombocytopenia, it is not as common as gestational thrombocytopenia.

 

Option D. Malaria in pregnancy: Malaria can cause thrombocytopenia, but it is not the most common cause during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational thrombocytopenia is the most common cause of mild thrombocytopenia during pregnancy and is usually not associated with adverse outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the active management of the third stage of labor? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early cord clamping

 

Active Management of Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) consists of specific interventions designed to prevent postpartum hemorrhage. The standard components include administration of uterotonic drugs immediately after delivery of the baby, controlled cord traction for placental delivery, and uterine massage after placental delivery. Early cord clamping is not currently emphasized as a core component of AMTSL in modern obstetric practice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Controlled cord traction: This is a fundamental component of AMTSL. After administration of uterotonics, gentle traction is applied to the umbilical cord while counter-pressure is applied to the uterus to facilitate placental delivery while preventing uterine inversion.

 

Option C. Injection Methergine (Ergometrine): This uterotonic medication is used in the management of the third stage of labor. The dose is 0.2mg IV/IM with onset of action in 2-7 minutes and duration of 2-7 hours. While it has contraindications in hypertensive patients, it remains a component of AMTSL when appropriate.

 

Option D. Injection Syntocinon (Oxytocin): This is the primary uterotonic agent used in AMTSL. The standard dose is 10 units IM/IV with onset in 1-3 minutes. It promotes effective uterine contraction after delivery of the baby to minimize blood loss and facilitate placental separation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AMTSL consists of administration of uterotonics (oxytocin or ergometrine when appropriate), controlled cord traction, and uterine massage after placental delivery, with early cord clamping no longer being emphasized as a core component of this protocol.
